misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that a bubble sort implementation using nested loops where the outer loop iterates to `n-1` and the inner loop iterates to `n-1-i` will correctly sort all elements in an array of size `n`.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The classical inner loop condition for the bubble sort algorithm when iterating up to `n-1-i` (to avoid checking already sorted elements at the end) should use `j <= n - 2 - i` or, as implemented using a strict less than, `j < n - 1 - i`. Given the current structure `j < n - 1 - i` combined with accessing `scores[j + 1]`, the code correctly prevents an `IndexOutOfBoundsException` (since if `j=n-2-i`, `j+1=n-1-i`, which is the maximum index checked). The implementation is logically correct for ascending sorting `n` elements in parallel arrays. *This realization means the code is logically correct and there is no conceptual gap related to the sorting itself.* The resulting output is derived from the last element, which holds the maximum value after sorting.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: None (Code is logically correct for the task objective and successfully finds the maximum score/name pair). The initial assessment that there was a boundary error was incorrect upon detailed inspection of the loop bounds.

evidence.code_snippet: for (int j = 0; j < n - 1 - i; j++) {
